title: Hackers Can Take Control Of Your Phone, If You Click On A Harmful GIF On WhatsApp

Hackers Can Take Control Of Your Phone, If You Click On A Harmful GIF On WhatsApp

Hackers Can Take Control Of Your Phone, If You Click On A Harmful GIF On WhatsApp

Facebook-owned WhatsApp is definitely one of the most popular texting apps in India. And it has also been one of the least secure with so many vulnerabilities now and then, causing havoc for its users.

Now, a new vulnerability for WhatsApp has surfaced that can give hackers gain access to your phone -- with the help of harmful GIFs.

Reuters/Rawpixel

Reported first by TNW, the vulnerability was discovered by a researcher that calls himself 'Awakened'. According to him, this is a double-free bug which basically means this attack could apply a memory corruption anomaly that could crash the app or open the gates for hackers to gain complete access to your phone.

According to Awakened, the main flaw resides in the way WhatsApp views gallery images on its app. He also states that the flaw is specifically dangerous for phones running on Android 8.1 and 9.0, whereas on older phones, the app just crashes and prevents giving access of the phone to the hackers.

WhatsApp also gave an official statement to TNW, while also revealing that the patch for the bug has been released in the latest update and urges everyone to update their apps to stay safe from this vulnerability.

Reuters

As per the official statement: "The key point that the (vulnerability disclosure) makes is that this issue affects the user on the sender side, meaning the issue could in theory occur when the user takes action to send a GIF. The issue would impact their own device. It was reported and quickly addressed last month. We have no reason to believe this affected any users though of course we are always working to provide the latest security features to our users."

Oddly enough, Awakened contacted TNW and disagreed with the aforementioned claim by WhatsApp, stating that the spokesperson might have misunderstood the issue. He also shared a proof-of-concept video revealing the vulnerability and how it works.
